X+1=5 How many solutions of this equation? One. that is x=4 X^2+1=5 by using the quadratic formula we get x= 2, -2 X^3-4x^2-x=-6 by using synthetic division we get (x-3)(x-2)(x+1)=0 .so x= -1,2,3 See any pattern?

There are plenty of applications of imaginary numbers that have nothing to do with faster than the speed of light.   For instance, the impedance of a capacitor is -i/(2*pi*f*C), or as electrical engineers like to state it, 1/(j*omega*C), because i is already spoken-for to stand for current.

Complex Analysis by lang (4th edition) : book uses alpha=a+bi....  def: "The real number b is called the imaginary part of alpha, and denoted by Im(alpha)"
well i don't know what that book is or what it's trying to say, but if you have 2 + 3i, the imaginary part is not 3, as 3 is not imaginary. 3i is imaginary, so bi is a pure imaginary number.
Complex Variables with Applications by Wunsch:   "We say that a is the real part of z and that b is the imaginary part."
yes bi is a pure imaginary number whose imaginary part is b.

if b is the imaginary part, then what is i? i is the fundamental imaginary number, so how is that not the imaginary part? you don't need to keep quoting things, just use your head. integers are not imaginary.

It's like having a 2D vector <a,b>.  we can write it in terms of the basis vectors <1,0> and <0,1> as <a,b>=a<1,0>+b<0,1>.   so we move a units in the <1,0> direction and b units in the <0,1> direction.  now instead of writing it as <a,b> we use a+bi.  we sill move a units in the real direction and b units in the imaginary direction.  so the real part is a and the imaginary part (the number of units moved in the imaginary direction) is b.

the number of units moved in the imaginary direction is still a real number. if you move three units in the imaginary direction, the number "three", is real. so i understand what you're saying, and perhaps this is an issue of semantics, but all imaginary numbers have i in them, period.

I never said that they don't have i (all complex numbers written in standard from have an i in them), but, by definition, the imaginary part of z=a+bi is b.  If you have a definition that differs from this I would love to know where you got it.  I have studied Mathematics for a long time and I know of no other definition that contradicts the one I have given.
well, then i trust you, but must take up a dispute with the definition, as it makes no sense to me.

I know this is an old comment thread and I have a really long comment but I wanted to do my best to try to explain why the definition does not include i in the imaginary part because I have done a decent amount of research so far during my math major on the topic and I recommend you to read more on complex variables and analysis as well to back up my claims. I guess the best way to explain why we don’t include the imaginary unit i in the definition of the imaginary part of a complex number is simply because it’s easier to work with. It basically comes down to understanding why we even care to take note of a complex number’s real and imaginary parts. One major reason is for determining equality between complex numbers since two complex numbers are equal if and only if they have the same real parts and the same imaginary parts. When you compare complex numbers in this way, what you are ultimately doing is comparing the real numbers found within the complex number. Technically in mathematics, we can come up with our own definitions for objects that we may encounter; however, what ultimately matters when we define new objects is making sure our definitions are consistent with our other definitions in mathematics, and that they are as useful as possible. Including i in the imaginary part of a complex number does not break any mathematical truth or physical law or anything but it serves no purpose and just makes calculations involving the real and imaginary parts redundant. Although it’s true that the imaginary unit is necessary for one to identify which part of a complex number is imaginary or real, when I communicate the value of the imaginary part, it is only necessary and way more efficient to communicate with the real coefficient. It’s like if someone asks you what color your shirt is and you respond “It’s a red shirt.” By using the word shirt again, it is not incorrect, but it is redundant since it is implied by the question that your answer will refer to your shirt and nothing else, so a response like “It is red,” communicates a more concise answer. A similar conundrum that I see people get confused over is how one defines the square root function. Since every real number has two square roots, one may think that the radical symbol implicitly includes both roots, but including both roots implicitly makes arithmetic with square roots much more confusing and makes the square root harder to define as a function. Instead, many mathematicians use the radical without any sign to mean the principal square root or positive square root. For example, sqrt(9) could equal 3 or -3 implicitly, but in order to make a calculation like 5+sqrt(3), simple, we take sqrt(9)=3, -sqrt(9)=-3, and + or -sqrt(9)= + or -3. This standard definition is not the only possible definition and seemingly contradicts our knowledge that every number inherently has two roots, but this definition allows us to still have both roots at our disposal (so we don’t contradict the known truth that every positive real number has two square roots) but with the requirement of an explicit sign change outside of the radical in order to simplify calculations and definitions. This is very similar to the case of defining the imaginary part of a complex number as only the real coefficient of the imaginary unit in the complex number. For example, if we want to calculate the modulus or absolute value of a complex number, z= x + iy, we use the complex plane and form a right triangle and from Pythagorean’s theorem get that |z|=sqrt(x^2+y^2). The modulus is still the distance of the number from zero so it must be a real number and it must be positive. From the standard definition of the real and imaginary parts of the complex number, we see that we can replace these inside of the equation, so   |z|= sqrt(Re(z)^2+Im(z)^2) where Re(z)= a and Im(z)=b. There is a clean translation between the definition of the complex number and its modulus if we stick the definition that both the real and imaginary parts are real numbers and this is showcased in many other areas involving complex numbers whether they are simple arithmetic or complex analysis. In summary, the ultimate point of defining the imaginary part as the real number coefficient of the imaginary unit i is to both simplify calculations involving complex numbers and to allow one to describe complex numbers in terms of 2 real numbers (the real part and imaginary part). By calling one part, the imaginary part, we implicitly understand that the original complex number uses this number as the coefficient for the imaginary unit i like every other complex number but it is the real number coefficient that gives the information that we need in the most concise manner possible as the imaginary unit i gives redundant information.
